awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Securing the Timing of Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses timing attacks in cyber-physical systems, where attackers attempt to compromise the system functionality by changing the timing of computation and communication operations. Timing attacks could be particularly destructive for cyber-physical systems because the correctness of system functionality is affected not only by the data values of operations but also significantly by at what time operations are conducted. The discoveries and methodologies developed in this project will provide fundamental advances in addressing timing attacks, and lead to the design and implementation of more secure cyber-physical systems in a number of key sectors, including automotive and transportation systems, industrial automation, and robotics. In addition to disseminate the research results through publications and workshops, the PIs will collaborate with industry partners on transitioning the research findings into practice. The PIs will also integrate the research into the curriculum at UCR and leverage it for K-12 education through the use of Lego Mindstorm platforms.

The project will build a framework for identifying, analyzing and protecting cyber-physical systems against timing attacks. Building the framework consists of three closely-related research thrusts: 1) Investigate potential timing-based attack surface, and further analyze what types and patterns of timing variations the attacks may cause and how attackers may try to hide the traces of such attacks. 2) Based on the identified attack surface and strategies, analyze how timing changes caused by these attacks may affect the overall system properties, in particular safety, stability and performance. 3) Develop control-based and cyber-security defense strategies against timing attacks. This includes run-time security detectors and mitigation/adaptation strategies across control layer and embedded system layer, as well as design-time mechanisms to provide systems that are resilient to timing attacks. This project will focus on vehicle networks and multi-agent robotic systems as main application domains.

por.por_cntn:
Timing attacks, where attackers attempt to compromise the timing of computation or communication operations, can be particularly destructive to cyber-physical systems (CPSs) because the correctness of CPS functionality is affected not only by the data values of operations but also by the time those operations are conducted. This project developed novel methods and tools for identifying, analyzing and defending against timing attacks in CPS, and applied them to the domains of connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) and multi-agent robotic systems, with the former being the main application driver. Some highlights of the project outcome include methods for designing resilient connected vehicle applications under communication disturbance, algorithms and tools for formal verification and adaptation of CPS under execution timing violations, and control-theoretical approaches for resilient network systems, as introduced below.

Connected vehicle resiliency: Connected vehicle (CV) applications have shown great promises in improving transportation safety and efficiency, however, many of them are highly vulnerable to timing attacks such as flooding and jamming of the communication channels in ad-hoc vehicular network. This project started with investigating the impact of timing attacks on two CV applications: collaborative adaptive cruise control (CACC) and intelligent intersection management, and developed novel delay-tolerant protocols that can guarantee system safety under communication delays and message losses. It demonstrated that the proposed delay-tolerant autonomous intersection design can significantly outperform smart traffic lights that use back pressure based scheduling, even when under timing attacks. The project then extended its learnings from these two applications to others, and developed a general framework for modeling, simulation, synthesis and verification of CV applications, with consideration of communication disturbances. At the device level, the project investigated security issues of commercial V2X (vehicle-to-everything) communication modules, and identified potential vulnerabilities in timing synchronization. It also investigated novel vulnerabilities in the DNS infrastructure and their impact on V2X communication, and discovered a novel DNS flaw that can cause resolver and forwarder caches to be poisoned with malicious records. This could affect vehicles that rely on the DNS infrastructure, which can potentially allow an attacker to become a Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) intercepting all the messages between two vehicles, and could also affect the vehicles rely on NTP servers (using domain names) to synchronize time. The project evaluated the seriousness of the DNS cache poisoning attack against general public DNS services and showed that it applies to a large fraction of them.

Formal verification and adaptation of CPS under timing violations: Many CPSs, such as CAVs and various robotic systems, operate in highly dynamic and uncertain environment and could be under constant disturbances that cause timing violations in their execution, which may lead to unsafe scenarios and disastrous consequences. To address this challenge, the project applied weakly-hard constraints to formally capture the degree of timing violations to system functions, and developed formal techniques to verify the safety of those functions under such bounded timing violations. An open-source tool SAW for this work is released on GitHub (https://github.com/551100kk/SAW). The project also developed safety-assured runtime adaptation methods that can address the system adaptation needs when they are under disturbances, by automatically switching the system control among multiple controllers, including neural network controllers, with safety guarantees. Finally, the project developed methods to improve system resiliency by leveraging the intrinsic robustness of certain system functions to add additional security monitoring and fault tolerance tasks, which is particularly useful for system retrofitting under limited resources.

Control-theoretical approaches for resilient network systems: From control-theoretic perspective, the project investigated the use of V2X communication to partially influence routing decisions of drivers in transportation systems. The project defined link-wise levels of trust to tolerate the non-cooperative behavior of part of the drivers population, and a real-time update mechanism to take into account sudden changes in the levels of trust. The results imply that using V2X communication should be carefully addressed to guarantee the resiliency of the infrastructure. The project also studied the stability of the equilibrium points of traffic networks under real-time app-informed routing, proposed a dynamical routing model to describe the real-time route selection mechanism that is at the core of app-informed routing, and leveraged the theory of passivity in nonlinear dynamical systems to provide a theoretical framework to explain emerging dynamical behaviors in real-world networks.

The research findings from this project provided fundamental advances in addressing CPS security and resiliency. The knowledge and solutions gained for application domains such as CAV could have significant practical values and societal impacts. The findings have been disseminated to the public through more than 30 publications at top conferences and journals, as well as open-source software tools. They have also been incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate courses at Northwestern University and UC Riverside. Through the project, the PIs have mentored more than 20 graduate students and postdocs. They also closely collaborated with industry partners, with joint publications.
